title: Wednesday, 8th August, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

There's a lesser known Chinese curse, "may you live in idiotic times".

Blank canvas morning all
DRichi Good morning
Manxish Morning each
BE11:04am

And truly, we are living through The Age of The Curs'ed.

Soundbuy Hi
BE11:05am

Of course ... Of course! ...... I'm talking about this.

11:04 am
BE11:05am

https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1026872652290379776

BE11:05am

And let's be cleaer, it makes no sense. None. Zero. Nil.

PaulH Hiya
BE11:05am

It's complete batshit nonsense.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

From a financing perspective, from a legal perspective, from a logic perspective.

BE11:05am

The actual words in the tweet don't even make sense! How would it be a take-private by Elon if his percentage stake remains the same?

BE11:06am

(Welcome to Markets Live, BTW. FT Alphaville's thing with the stuff.)

11:05 am
BE11:06am

So ....... what's really going on here?

BE11:06am

I don't know! Not a clue! But like everyone else, I can speculate.

BE11:06am

Here's Speculation One ....

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Musk woke up in his tent, read the FT scoop overnight about the Saudi SWF holding sub 5% of Tesla, and decided to double down with a public airing of his take-private fantasy as a way to burn the shorts.

BE11:06am

Perhaps he figured that the mention of an SWF would neutralise awkward questions about who'd fund this nonsense.

BE11:07am

Which'd be pretty quick thinking for so early in the morning.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

So ......... One of the interesting lines in the FT's initial story was that the Saudis approached Tesla looking to buy new equity, but were turned away, and so bought in the secondary market.

BE11:07am

Now to the average person, it seems about 10,000% more likely that a SFW would act as a cornerstone investor for future equity raise

Soundbuy All a bit whiffy...........
BE11:08am

That looks a more attractive option than bankrolling a lolBO of a company with no cashflow and negative EV/EBITDA in the 150s.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

However, launching a cash call with Saudi backing would look awkward for Tesla on two separate fronts.

Bmx Possibly old news, but I read there's some "hidden" jokes in that Musk tweet. 420 being one reference, and the total valuation landing around $69bn..
chad_john But all of that is surely, er, at the boundaries of legal. Right?
VV75 this will get him fired, clear attempt at market manipulation
BE11:09am

It might be more palatable now an even more absurd idea is out there, though.

BE11:09am

Which would lead us towards a conclusion that the whole $420 take-private thing's a MacGuffin.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MacGuffin

BE11:09am

In fiction, a MacGuffin (sometimes McGuffin or maguffin) is a plot device in the form of some goal, desired object, or another motivator that the protagonist pursues, often with little or no narrative explanation. The MacGuffin's importance to the plot is not the object itself, but rather its effect on the characters and their motivations.

BE11:09am

That's Speculation One. And Here's Speculation Two ....

11:09 am
BE11:10am

It was a dumb joke! A dumb, unfunny joke!

BE11:10am

But it was a dumb joke that Tesla suits had to lean into, because the consequences of saying "lol, kidding" were too great.

BE11:10am

The Age of Idiocy means we have precedent for this kind of thing.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

President, in fact.

BE11:10am

BE11:11am

The "Trump White House Resort and Casino" jokes?

11:10 am

chopper bear spire still getting roasted

In that context, is it implausible that we'll get the biggest ever take-private because of a dumb joke that went too far so had to be taken seriously?

BE11:17am

The funding of the transaction is unclear, but is potentially less of an obstacle than obtaining shareholders’ approval, in our view. We consider the $420/share proposal as low and believe the fair value per share is higher at $500.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The move to potentially take Tesla private would undoubtedly have wide-ranging implications for the entire automotive industry. However, despite the market’s surprise at Mr Musk’s announcement, such a move is perhaps easier to justify than it initially seems. It removes Tesla from the glare of the public market’s shorttermism, allowing the company easier access to funding sources that are more aligned with Mr Musk’s longer-term ambitions. Furthermore, with potentially less burdensome disclosure requirements, the company will likely find itself more nimble in addressing opportunities to expand its regional footprint and product portfolio, without the pressure of shortterm financial targets.

VV75 fair value above 500? somebody's been smoking something there
comm_1100 would be a shame if TSLA goes private, was just starting to enjoy CEOs talking to random youtubers for an hour on earnings calls
BE11:18am

If the proposal is approved, shareholders who value the company above $420/share may still choose to retain ownership in a privately owned Tesla. By allowing existing shareholders to participate in the transition, the deal should largely preserve the current shareholder structure. As with SpaceX, there will be no liquid secondary market, except for periodic events when shares in the private company can be traded. With respect to shareholders who choose to accept cash, funding for the transaction will likely be raised from strategic investors and/or debt – a scenario in which 20% of shares are exchanged for cash would imply that funding of around $14bn is required.

BE11:19am

JP Morgan remain sellers.

Joanna W SEC rules - private company cannot have >500 shareholders??? How can existing shareholders participate
11:19 am
BE11:19am

As surprising to us as these developments are, and as lacking as the statements are in any details regarding who is expected to provide the required amount of financing and on what terms, they are nevertheless declarative statements from the CEO of a public company which we feel should be considered seriously. Either funding is secured or it is not secured, and Tesla’s CEO says funding is secured. Therefore, we are incorporating into our valuation the real possibility the equity will be taken out at $420 per share. Separate from the Twitter statements, the company also made public a letter Mr. Musk had written to Tesla employees in which he states, “If the process ends the way I expect it will, a private Tesla would ultimately be an enormous opportunity for all of us.” To us, this suggests more than mere consideration — Mr. Musk expects Tesla will go private. We are not as certain, and so assign only a 50% probability to such a scenario in our updated valuation. We continue to believe Tesla’s valuation based on fundamentals alone (i.e., a 50/50 blend of DCF and 2020-based multiples analysis — itself consisting of a blend of P/E, EV/EBITDA, and Price-to-Sales) is worth no more than $195 (our previous price target). But introducing a new 50% weighting of $420 suggests a large upward revision to our price target is warranted, and we newly value Tesla at $308 per share (i.e., 50/50 blend of $195 and $420).

BE11:20am

I'm really enjoying the sellside taking this errant nonsense seriously.

Tom Dalgleish I suppose that's Beven Vs The Spectator again
Tom Dalgleish *Bevan
BE11:20am

Morgan Stanley:

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Tesla has long relied on public markets to fund its ambitious plan and has
used its highly priced equity and equity-linked currency to its advantage
since 2010.
Taking the company private would assume one of 2 factors changing: (1)
that the company is on the verge of generating self-sustaining cash flows
or (2) that the company can tap into a range of strategic sources of capital
not previously at its disposal.

BE11:21am

We see the benefits of potentially being private outweighed by risks of
added financial leverage which can be even more strategically limiting…
There remains a significant amount of near-term execution risk around the Model 3 ramp as well as medium-to-long-term ability to generate
sustainable levels of cash flow. Adding as much as $50bn of net debt to
the capital structure (70% debt assumption in our model) would clearly
intensify the outcomes of such an action.

#REF! why bother on the sellside covering Tesla? share price dominated by message boards not institutions... in some ways like a aim penny stock...
BE11:21am

If Tesla’s CEO really wanted to go private… why announce it to the world
in this way… which could significantly contribute to the required premium
and financial leverage? For much of the past few months, Tesla’s CEO has
made statements directly engaging investors and at many times making
supportive statements to the share price. Investors might reasonably ask
why Tesla management would want the stock price to reflect all the
premium of an LBO up-front. It is hard to understand the potential reason
for such a negotiating strategy.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

At first blush, the LBO math required to support $420 is extremely
aggressive, in our view. The inputs and outputs are certainly open to
interpretation. We ran our proprietary 5-year mini-LBO model on our Tesla
forecasts assuming a 30% equity slug/70% leverage, 10.0% blended cost
of new debt and a range of exit EBITDA margin and exit multiple
assumptions. We ran our model starting year-end 2018 (assuming a
potential transaction would require the remainder of the calendar year for
shareholder approval and financing). Assuming a 20% hurdle rate (IRR)
over the time horizon (2018 through 2023) among a range of assumptions,
Tesla would require EBITDA margins of around 15% (BMW or Mercedes-
Benz territory) with a 15x exit EBITDA multiple (Ferrari territory) to support
a $420 valuation. Other combinations of assumptions include a 20% exit
EBITDA margin (approaching Porsche territory) with an 11x exit EBITDA
multiple to support $420. Yet another combination to support a $420
valuation could include an 11% EBITDA margin (GM-esque) and 20x
EV/EBITDA (Ferrari peak EBITDA multiple).

DRichi August really is quiet if sellside have time enough to write so much about so little. Dumb tweet- best to just ignore (easy to say for someone without twitter but the principle holds true regardless)
BE11:22am

But with the fanbois onboard, what about an LBO lite?

BE11:22am

If Mr. Musk wants to
achieve private company status while maintaining leverage in the 5 to 10x
range, then his skills of raising equity capital would really be put to the
test. Running our base case LBO assumptions (15% EBITDA margin and 15x
EV/EBITDA multiple) at 50% equity and 8% blended cost of debt yields a
17% IRR at $420 (vs. 20% IRR at 30% equity). Running the model with 70%
equity and a 6% blended cost of debt yields a 14% IRR.

And Jefferies:

BE11:24am

Distraction or not, the move feels right even if Musk is downplaying how
supportive public markets have been. With Tesla unable to take on more
debt, we wonder who may fund the potential deal and end up as a new large shareholder. We raise estimates to reflect a better outlook post Q2. Our DCF fair value points to $300 and our new $360 PT bridges the gap to the $420 potential bid.

BE11:24am

If the Saudis had taken the sub 5% stake on the knowledge that a take-private was in the works, wouldn't that be insider trading?

BE11:27am

And Cowen.

BE11:27am

Tesla is in a box as it needs cash to fund its aspirational growth initiatives and ultimate mission while at the same time needing to gear up to deal with rapidly maturing debt loads. The expectation of future growth coupled with long-term profits has kept the valuation lofty in recent years, and the story has always been able to raise capital when needed. Market dynamics are changing, competition is coming, the company has over-promised and under delivered consistently, which has heightened investor anxiety leading to the heavy short interest. While we could be proven wrong with our cautious view on shares should the company successfully raise the capital needed to go private, we continue to have numerous concerns about the company's mid to long term positioning and see the current valuation divorced from fundamentals. We see the stock range bound at current levels until funding details emerge.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Outstanding Questions:
■ The outcome largely hinges on what "funding is secured" means. What are the plans for
capital funding plans for going forward post the potential transaction? We continue to see
the company's capital needs as much higher than the company is able to generate from
operations under optimistic scenarios.
■ How would the structure work as a private company given Elon Musk's intention to allow
individual investors to remain shareholders? Mr. Musk promised that it is not about taking
the control of the company and would remain an owner at about 20%.
■ It is obvious to see how such a transaction would benefit a CEO who has been very
distracted by social media and is focused on "burning shorts", but we question how
remaining investors would benefit from a less liquid structure in which management
receives far less scrutiny despite its historically poor execution and track record.
■ What is the impact for convertible debt? Note Tesla has an inherent bias to keep the stock
above the convertible debt conversion price of $359.87 per the $920 million tranche that
converts in March 2019. There is also a $320 million tranche due in November 2018.
■ Is this program Board approved? Was the board involved in the choice to release details
of the potential transaction over Twitter rather than issuing an 8-K? Have attorneys and
bankers been hired already, otherwise this Tweet seems aspirational, in our view.

chad_john I wish I had the ability to move prices via a tweet, though. What a gift.
BE11:28am

We've asked similar questions over here: https://ftalphavil...have-questions---/

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Monday’s profit warning means we now have even less certainty of a nearterm improvement in Spire’s fortunes since: 1) the visibility of NHS market factors that are affecting the company’s growth has declined over the last six months; and 2) cost growth has been more rapid than expected, and is not explained fully by cost inflation and the investment announced five months ago. Given that guidance was reiterated 10 weeks ago, operations have clearly taken a marked turn for the worse, and the lack of new guidance indicates that management is currently unable to forecast its own business. Only when this is possible, and when we regain confidence that the five-year history of earnings downgrades is over, can we look further ahead to its 2022 targets, which themselves imply that Spire will have greater control over the market than we believe is possible.

dorsetcontrarian morning all - mkts up, tesla up & all is well with the world
Soundbuy @chopper - Spire............you got the pointy end......
BE11:33am

In the meantime, we downgrade our 2018 EBITDA by 16% and EPS by 37%, noting that this implies gearing of 3.7x EBITDA at the end of 2018 (covenant 4.0x). With the shares down by 20% since our upgrade, our waning confidence in our prior investment thesis prompts us to consider a stop-loss action. Our new valuation, based on EV/EBITDA and DCF metrics that reflect higher risk, leads to a 120p/share price target. We therefore set our recommendation to Sell, and believe there is potential for intangible asset write-downs and a dividend cut. Speculation regarding the potential for Mediclinic to acquire Spire helps to the limit downside, but Mediclinic’s five-year low share price, and the negative reaction to its previous bid for Spire, adds risk to relying on that get-out-of-jail-free card.

To factor in the higher risk from lower visibility and greater gearing, we reduce our applied EBITDA multiple from 9x to 7x and our terminal growth from 2% to 1%, and we increase our cost of equity to 14-
15%. Our price target is 120p, and we see a trade sale as the key upside risk.

Prudential reported its 1H18 results wherein the headline operating earnings came in well above our and consensus expectation at £2.4bn. However this included one-offs in the UK of c. £229m and excluding the impact of these, underlying earnings are 3.4% below our forecast. This miss came from US earnings whereas
Asian earnings were inline with expectations. To us the underwhelming part was the new business sales in Asia
which declined by 4% on constant currency basis and even after excluding the impact of HK sales drop, the new
business sales in Asia increase by just 1% YoY due to declining sales in Malaysia/Indonesia/India offset by other markets. Solvency II ratio was better than expectation at 209% vs. JPMe 206% and DPS came inline at 15.67p a share.

BE11:45am

RBC's reliably good at miners:

BE11:45am

Our view: The 3% miss to consensus EBITDA (7% vs. RBC) and the increased cost guidance for FY18 is likely to be the focus of today’s results, but seasonality of production and copper sales as well as the magnitude of the impact from bi-product credits within Glencore’s cost base are likely to see full-year consensus estimates relatively unchanged. H2 is likely to drive some catch up for the one-off nature of the sales impact. Glencore now guides for costs based on spot prices. Following weak cobalt, copper, silver and gold prices to the August 3 spot date, a large portion of the uptick in 2018 cost guidance (copper from 83 cents to 103 cents, zinc from -11 to -3 cents, coal from $50/t to $52/t) is by-product and/or mix related (guided coal margin now $44/t up from $35/t though). This said, costs are appearing to increase on an industry wide basis and this has impacted Glencore to an extent. Marketing was 1% better at the EBIT level than our forecasts with a strong metals and mining contribution offset by still challenging agriculture segment dynamics.

Stateless also @mouselet exactly this is why people should stay off twitter
11:45 am
BE11:45am

In addition to the $1billion buyback announced in July (ongoing), the company has also bought back $300m of treasury shares. Net debt at $9.0bn was below our estimates in part because RMI’s at $22.8bn were higher than our forecasts, although this is likely compressing alongside the lower price environment; leaving our full-year ND forecast still reasonable based on our current commodity price assumptions. Although there is no “big bang” within today’s results, with ND to EBITDA at 0.55x and as Glencore highlights in its results presentation, and as we’ve highlighted here, the company is trading at a substantial discount to peers on a free cash yield basis with a strong balance sheet. This should open up more compelling opportunities for buybacks into 2019 or other options to compress this valuation disconnect. We expect the shares to trade lower this morning but continue to point to a strong medium-term value case. Glencore is trading on spot 3.4x EV/EBITDA.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 324.50, down 1.8 (-0.55%), High: 327.45, Low: 315.00, Volume: 14.95m

Industrials EBITDA at USD6.6bn was 4% lighter than consensus, but we note that central costs, which were H1 weighted (FY guidance unchanged), accounted for half of this USD300m difference. The other half was driven by restart costs at Lady Loretta (higher zinc volumes in H2), lower coal volumes in Colombia weighing on fixed costs, the relining of Mount Isa in copper as well as greater third-party feed costs at Mopani. Higher fuel and other energy costs were offset by higher coal prices over H1.

Running current [weaker] spot prices for 12 months points to an EBITDA of USD17.6bn as per Glencore’s illustrative sensitivity, fully in line with our mark-to-market model at USD17.7bn. Running H2 at spot and adding the reported H1 would give a group EBITDA of USD19.3bn, 8% above the latest pre-results consensus mean of USD17.8bn. FY18 marketing EBIT guidance was confirmed in the top half of the USD2.2bn-3.2bn range, with the midpoint at USD2.95bn.

BE12:09pm

Paddy Power Betfair’s (PPB) H1 results point to solid progress on
the revenue front, with a particularly strong improvement in
gaming revenue (Q2 +14% versus -4% in Q1). However,
exchange performance will disappoint, as competition seems to
be increasing. While management has lowered FY 2018 EBITDA
guidance to £460-480m, this is largely explained by earlier
Australian taxes (which we have accounted for) and FanDuel
losses from daily fantasy (which wasn’t in our numbers). Post
adjustments to divisional estimates, we expect to keep our FY
2018 EBITDA broadly the same at circa £470m.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

And Goodbody.

BE12:10pm

Overall, there are positives and negatives in this morning’s release. However, we are encouraged by the improving momentum seen across the group in Q2. The key stand-out is the better performance at PaddyPower.com, while Australia and the US remain in very good shape. The exchange performance is slightly weaker than anticipated but growth elsewhere in online is more than offsetting this. Retail is slightly weaker, but we continue to like the group’s competitive positioning relative to peers in advance of machines changes. In terms of our forecasts, we are likely to reduce our FY18 EBITDA by c.2% from £480m (mainly due to higher losses from daily fantasy sports in H2). On a positive note, the majority of underlying trends are pointing in the right direction. These, along with its US strategy, give us comfort in the long-term growth potential of the group. BUY.

BE12:10pm

And Peel Hunt.

12:10 pm
BE12:11pm

Management is delivering the promised strategy but in an
unforgiving world. The outstanding performance of the
Australian business is being undermined at the bottom line by
fees and taxes and the Exchange, a material source of profit, is
feeling the effects of competition. More delivery at the bottom
line is needed to get the share price moving.

BE12:11pm

Overall with the shares having rallied off the lows and on an FY18E PE of
c20x, we expect the market to be pretty unforgiving of the downgrade and
reiterate our Reduce recommendation and 7,500p target price.

BE12:11pm

Fair enough.
